intro: Lobelia shaferi var. obtusata, commonly known as the Shafer's lobelia, is a rare and striking member of the Campanulaceae family. It is characterized by its distinctive, spurred flowers that range in color from blue to purple, often with a contrasting yellow or white base. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices, preferring cool and humid conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its ornamental appeal. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable subject for botanical study and conservation efforts.
